element.name: Trauma Triage Criteria (Steps 1 and 2)
element.definition: Physiologic and Anatomic Field Trauma Triage Criteria (steps 1 and 2) as defined by the Centers for Disease Control.
element.v3Comment: 2011 Guidelines for the Field Triage of Injured Patients - value choices for Steps 1 and 2. For falls, one story is equal to 10 feet.
element.v3Changes:
Added to better evaluate the CDC-ACS 2011 Guidelines for the Field Triage of Injured Patients.
Website: http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/rr/rr6101.pdf

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: Amputation proximal to wrist or ankle

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: Crushed, degloved, mangled, or pulseless extremity

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: Chest wall instability or deformity (e.g., flail chest)

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: All penetrating injuries to head, neck, torso, and extremities proximal to elbow or knee

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: Respiratory Rate <10 or >29 breaths per minute (<20 in infants aged <1 year) or need for ventilatory support

facet.name: enumeration
facet.annotation: Two or more proximal long-bone fractures

asserts.assert: Trauma Triage Criteria (Steps 1 and 2) should only be recorded when Possible Injury is "Yes".
When Trauma Triage Criteria (Steps 1 and 2) has a Not Value (Not Applicable, Not Recorded, or Not Reporting), it should be empty.

When Trauma Triage Criteria (Steps 1 and 2) is empty, it should have a Not Value (Not Applicable, Not Recorded, or Not Reporting, if allowed for the element) or a Pertinent Negative (if allowed for the element), or it should be omitted (if the element is optional).
